newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper ends off, LME stock puzzle continues.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper ends off, LME stock puzzle continues.

text.p: COMEX copper ended weaker despite a further sharp drop in LME stocks Tuesday and news of the arrest of Yasuo Hamanaka, the disgraced former head trader at the heart of the Sumitomo Corp copper scandal.
LME stocks tumbled 13,075 tonnes, in line with trade expectations. The drop was already factored into the market, a broker said.
Stocks at Long Beach, Calif. fell 3,000 tonnes to 40,125 tonnes. LME stocks have fallen by about 100,000 tonnes in recent weeks while prices have failed to rally convincingly.
COMEX warehouse stocks rose 1,469 short tons to 22,314 short tons Tuesday.
December COMEX settled 0.55 cent weaker at 92.45 cents per pound, traded narrowly between 93.00 and 92.00 cents.
Volume was estimated at 9,000 lots compared to Monday's official 9,120 lots.

News that Hamanaka has been arrested on suspicion of forging documents used in metal trades with U.S. broker Merrill Lynch failed to move a market which traders believed the Japanese trader dominated for so long.
Unions at Kennecott Copper tentatively agreed a new deal.
The Utah producer was hit by a two-day strike last week.
Meanwhile Bloomsbury Minerals Economic Limited said world refined copper surplus is likely to reach 100,000 tonnes this year.
Much of the large amount of metal drawn from LME stocks in recent weeks was sent to Chinese state stockpiles and has not been consumed, Bloomsbury said.
An LME and COMEX broker said there were going to be further drawdowns in LME stocks over the coming weeks, but there is no agreement where all the metal is going.
Attractive arbitrage rates have made it profitable to take metal out of Hamburg or Long Beach for shipment to COMEX warehouses in San Manuel or to U.S. consumers, brokers said.

"But the fact that there is no metal going into LME warehouses means to me that there is still a relative tightness," the broker said. "All this new production talked about has not filtered through the system yet."
